Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Effects of individual ozone exposure on lung function in the elderly: a cross-sectional study in China.

AbstractText: The aim of this study was to assess the acute health effects of individual ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) exposure on the respiratory system in the elderly. A total of 40 non-smoking elderly volunteers completed personal 24 h of measurement for O<sub>3</sub> and fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>). To assess health effects, we measured the pulmonary function and five inflammatory biomarkers in exhaled breath condensate (EBC), including interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon-γ (IFN-γ), prostaglandin E<sub>2</sub> (PGE<sub>2</sub>), and tumor necrosis factor α/β (TNFα/β). We used the generalized additive model to analyze the association between O<sub>3</sub> and these health effects, after adjusting PM<sub>2.5</sub>, BMI, and sex as confounders. As a result, we found a negative correlation between O<sub>3</sub> and forced vital capacity (FVC) or forced expiratory volume-one second (FEV1). With the increasing of O<sub>3</sub> by 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, FVC and FEV1 decreased by 0.13 L (95% CI 0.01, 0.26) and 0.11 L (95% CI 0.02, 0.20), respectively. We found no statistical significance between O<sub>3</sub> and biomarkers in EBC. The results suggested that individual 24-h O<sub>3</sub> exposure was associated with decreased pulmonary function in the elderly.
